Josh ef yer wants it come an git it, dont I gine fling it erway, nothin but cuisness nohow,sav in dat thing. You does de cu- isest doics I ever knowed any nigger ter do. Aunt Patsy was cutting some meat and she found a bullet in it. Uncle Josh said  Hole on dar, Patsy, doan fling dat thing erway, ceze date de very bullet me an Marse John used ter kill all ole Marsters hogs wid, an I alius got hit out each hog an kill tothers wid it die time I shot hit little too hard, buc I knowed we would fine hit when we out dat shoulder. I saw the bullet and it really looked battered and worn, but how much of Uncle Joshs sto ry was true I dont know. He took the bullet, wrapped it carefully in a piece of tinfoil and put it in a little bottle and stopped it up and put it away saying  You njay do yer gruntin out dar now, but I sav in dis bullet.1 An old white hog was out in a pen olose by. document.text: William Pitzer Gills, who died at his home, Locust Grove, Friday morning, was the son of James Thomas and Cornelia Terri 1 Pitzer Gills. Though jiorn in Buckingham county, he moved to Appomattox in his boyhood on account of the death of his father. He then made his home with his uncle, the late Will iam Gills, who for many years was treasurer of the the county. He at tended the first public school evei taught in this county, Judge David A. Christian being the teacher. Mr. Gills engaged in various aeti- ties until the infirmities or age made, it necessary for him to retire from, public life. He was a senool trus.et of Appomattox county also serving as clerk to the school board, man carrier on R. F. D. No. 2, employed at one time by the Norfolk and Wes tern Railway, besides managing his arm near Appomattox. He was a iason and a Woodman of the  orld, and a Democr t who was un- werving in his par loyaly. Fii nany-lyears he was a faithful dea- on of Liberty Baptist church and teacher in the Sunday School. The deceased was a man whose lie was marked by fidelity to prin- ple. His was a goodly heritage of u ture and Godliness from an an cestry distinguished in the early history of America. Those who came in con4act with him were impressed by the deep spirituality of his nature. t  The funeral took place Sunday afternoon at Liberty Baptist church The Rev. H. Frederick Jones, the pastor, and the Rev. William May- field Thompson, a former pastor, conducting the services. The choir ,f the church sang Mr. Gills favor ite hymn, Rock of Ages. Tenny sons immortal poem, Crossing the Bar, was read and played on the pipe organ as a processional. Inter ment took place in the family plot in Liberty Cemetery, that part of the service. being conducted by the Masonic order. A host of friends and acquaintances, with many beautifa floral tributes attested to the love and high regard in which Mr. Gills was held in Appomattox and through out the state. Ihe active pallbearers were A. T. Inge, C. S. McDeormon, R. L. j Burk?, A. R. Harwood, J. C David son, N R. Featherston, B. G. An derson, Luther J. Morris. Honorary pallbearers included R. B. Hudgins, J. H. Lucado, T. W. Moses, Charles T. Moses, Pat Chand ler, L. Crawley, C. W. Smith, W. Stratton Taylor, Jennings Ferguson. T. Ed Owen, W. J. LeGrand, Dr. D. A. Christian, Dr. C. S an- ey, H. M. Burge, R. Travis Lee, F. A. OBrien, R. Edward OBrien, VV. W. OBrien, T. H. Inge, M. C. Imith, S. Guy Smith, R. C Wagner, J. A. Burke, Charlie Johnson, Pit zer Johnson, William Burke, D. A. Conner, D. E. Turnes, Jesse L. Tumes, James W. Caldwell, Harry Jenkins, Leonard Carter, E. Percy Sea, Odel! Howerton, Edmund H. Cawthorn, O. Cleveland Paulette. T. Morton Rosser, R. W. Smith, Leslie N. Ligon, L. E. Smith, C. N. Abbitt, J R Horsley, J. E. Chick, W. L. Brown, L. F. Ferguson, O P. Farrar, J. H. Cheatham, Dr. L L. Gayle, Dr. C. F. James, Robert Hubbard, Fitz Martin, Calvin H. Robinson, George F. Abbitt, Jr., T. W. Ferguson, Lester B. Harvey, J. D. Plunkett. Mr. Gills was first married to Miss Ella Pittman, who died some years ago. Two of the children of this union survive him, Henry Pitzer Gills of Marion, Virginia, and Mr 3 . Luth er B. Pittman, of Richmond. His second wife, who survives him, was Miss Albertha OBrien Of this mar riage, six children wire torn, James, passing away in inf.-ncy. The five living are Professor Allen Gils, of Clarksville Miss Cornelia Kyle Gills, of Appomattox Shelby Ken- nard Gills, of Richmond Mrs. Will iam Haller Copenhaver, of Marion Mrs. R. Banks Frazier, of Richmond. He also leaves five grandchildren, Mrs. R. S. Simpkins, of Chrisians- burg, Va. Mrs. Allen B. Pearcy, of Bristol, Penn. Joseph Pitzer Gills, of Pulaski, Va., Eloise Ogden, and Mary Joan Gills, of Clarksville, Va., and one brother, James T. Gills, of Lynchburg, his only other brother being the late Edmond Ernest Gills, of Appomattox. document.text: While a number of women are lob bying for the equal suffrage bill, it is said that at the public hearing Fri day afternoon a petition, signed by many prominent women,, was present ed, urging the committee not to rec ommend the measure for passage. Bills prohibiting the manufacture or sale of other than safety matches, to tax automobiles for county road purposes, to create a department of mines, to amend tax laws, reducing assessments on the first 1,000 of household goods from 35 cents to 10 cents to amend the code, and to prescribe order of procedure In court cases, were introduced. The Senate resolution, offered - by Senator Echols, of Augusta, for the formal election of United States sena tors at noon on Tuesday, January 23, and a joint election on Wednesday, the 24th, was concurred in by the House. The Senate concurred In a House resolution to arrange a joint session for February 22, when the State of Texas will present a portrait of Gen. Sam Houston to Virginia. Democratic Floor Leader Martin Williams, of Giles county, is strenu ously opposing the proposed tax com mission bill in Its present form, averr ing that it is not fair to Giles and other southwestern counties of the State rich in mineral deposits and other natural resources. Another measure which will meet with oppo sition is the Stenbenson bill to abol-, lsh gambling. Delegate Banks, from Norfolk, says the bill will mean the death of horseracing and bookmaking at the Jamestown racstrack. The Senate and House held a joint session and unanimously elected W. D. Saunders State dairy and food com missioner, and J. Richard Wingfield member of .the State Corporation Com mission. The House concurred in the Senate resolution to do away with the pres ent system of leasing convict labor, and calling upon the joint committees on roads to consider the Governors message relative to roads and work ing convicts thereon. Bills were introduced in the House to prohibit treating in saloons to place local milk inspectors under juris diction of the State Dairy and Pure rood Commission to compel State employes to work from 9 to 5 oclock each day. The Senate concurred iu the House rneasuYe to close the hunting season at once to protect game. One bill of State-wide interest in the Senate makes it necessary to se cure a State license to carry deadly or dangerous weapons. -Senator Paul, of the Republican mi nority, is working in the interest of a measure to have at least one Repub lican on every electoral board throughout the State. The bill for a change in the city charter of Richmond for the creation of an administrative board, previously passed by the House, was passed in the Senate under a suspension of the rules, and now goes to Governor Mann for his signature. Delegate Cox, of Richmond, intro duced a resolution providing that Gov ernor Woodrow Wilson, of New Jer sey, be invited to address  joint ses sion of the legislature and of the Rich mond City Council on Thursday night, February 1, at 8 oclock. The resolu tion was unanimously passed, and when sent to the Senate was concur red in. One of the most Important bills in troduced in the House was presented by Delegate Harwood, of Richmond, providing for the amendment to the section of the code governing the state tax on corporations for the sup port of free schools, pensions and liquidation of the public debt. The present law provides a maximum fee of 600, imposed upon a company with a capital of 1,000,000, while on a company capitalized at 999,000 the tax is 199.80. It was announced in both Houses that the joint committee on roads would have a public hearing on the questions of roads and workirfe con victs thereon, according to the recom mendations of Governor Mantl, on Monday, January ?9. One of the provisions of the charter amendment bill for the city of Rich mond, which has passed both Houses of the legislature and is now in thte hands of Governor Mann for his signature, reads that the city has the right to erect and maintain, in con nection with the city prison, if the I Council so determines, a suitable  workhouse and a bouse of correction, to compel and require all able-bodied i adult prisoners confined to perform anual labor in such workhouse and to  employ all youthful prisoners in the house of correction. Many representatives of the south west section of the state were here t,o oppose any changes in the redistrict ing of the Ninth district, the Dem ocrats believing that if the district is left undisturbed they have an excel lent chance to elect a successor to Congressman Bascom Slemp, the in cumbent, in the coming November election. , .

document.text: West Appomattox, Va., Sept. 1,1905. Mr. W. H. Camp, Petersburg, Va. Dear Sir Yours to hand and noted, and in reply will say I purchased two barrels of Camps Prepared Chemicals from your agent at. this point, Mr. Wingfield. I intend ed using it on corn, but as Commissioner of Revenue, I had lots of riding to do about that time and overlooked it. So when I came to plant tobacco I was iu a burry and did not tkc the time to mix it, but drilled it along side of a 3. 9. 8. guano, same proportion, 500 1 bs. to the acre, and I have never beeu able to tell the difference, It is ail fine tobacco. There is in experimenting station ou my farm, run .by the Bureau of Soils, and the Manager made considerable fun of me using Chemicafs. He seemed to doubt that it contained the ingredients it claimed to, so we drew a sample and he ook it to Washington and had it analysed. It ran 1 per cent higher on ammonia than you claimed and about the same ou potash. T know several parlies tha did use your chemicals according t. your directions this year with flue results. Very respectfully, II. C. BABCOCK

Mr. Frank Covington and Mr. and Mrs. James Bondurant visited Mr. and Mrs. Cecil Sells and family, of Princeton, W. Va., Saturday morning. We are so glad to hear Mrs. Sells is improving after a recent operation. Mr. and Mrs. Robert Coleman, Mrs. W. T. Coving ton, Mrs. Otis Smith and Mrs. James Conner spent Saturday in Farmville with Mr. and Mrs. Bennett Gilliam. We are glad Mr. Gilliam is home from the hospital and is improving nicely. Mr. and Mrs. Garland W. Banton, of Ashland, Ky., spent several days last week with Mr. antons mother, Mrs. C. R. Banton.
